item.title: Code should be clean because business isn't
item.description: I am an ardent capitalist. I am also an ardent Unix philosopher. I have long percieved there to be some interesting tensions between these two wolves inside me. The Unix philosopher in me wants my code to be as simple and flexible as possible, and - not always, but often - to minimize the number of lines of code I need to sling to solve a given problem.1 The capitalist in me wants to cover as many edge cases as possible, make every transition as smooth as possible, and apply as much napalm to the fire of user acquisition and douse its twin flame user churn in liquid death of another kind. What to do?

item.title: Why Does a PostgreSQL UPDATE Query Increase Table Size?
item.description:
The statement is ultimately false, but a single update query will cause the table's size to increase. This occurs due to PostgreSQL's storage model and its use of MVCC (Multi-Version Concurrency Control). To fully explain this, we must first understand these two concepts.
PostgreSQL's storage model
PostgreSQL stores all database

item.title: Kafka to HelixDB | langchain-beam
item.description: The Kafka to helixdb Pipeline is a pre-built Apache Beam streaming pipeline that lets you consume real-time text data from Kafka topics, generate embeddings using OpenAI models, and store the vectors into HelixDB node for similarity search and retrieval. The pipeline automatically handles windowing, embedding generation, and upserts to HelixDb's endpoint.

item.title: Vibe Coding Is Creating Braindead Coders
item.description: Confession: I‚Äôve been using Claude Code to write all my code for me. And I think it‚Äôs making me worse at the thing I‚Äôve loved doing for twelve years. I can clearly see how AI coding is rewiring our brains ‚Äì it makes developers crave instant gratification instead of deep understanding, and reduces us to gamblers who pull levers for the next hit of working code. If this is happening to me, someone who learned to code in the pre-AI era, what‚Äôs it doing to junior developers who‚Äôve never known anything else?

item.title: kkrieger: Making an Impossible FPS | Nostalgia Nerd
item.description:
Head to ‚Äãhttps://www.squarespace.com/nostalgianerd to save 10% off your first purchase of a website or domain using code NOSTALGIANERD.... The 90s and 00s demoscene was filled with incredible sights & sounds for the senses, but none more incredible (in my opinion) than kkrieger; a playable 3D FPS that compacts into just 96KB created by German demo group Farbrausch (theprodukkt). I'm fascinated by this, so it was amazing to get the chance to speak to some of the developers and designers of this monumental release and find out just how and why it was made. #fps #demoscene #kkrieger
Massive thanks to the demoscene legends; giZMo and ryg for their help & resources on this video. giZMo: https://twitter.com/chris_muetze ryg: https://twitter.com/rygorous
00:00 The demoscene 04:17 Farbrausch pre-kkrieger 07:27 Procedural texture generation 10:04 Integrated ad 10:51 Using external libraries 12:19 Bump maps and meshes 13:30 Tools of the trade (Werkkzeug) 14:36 Character modelling 16:34 Reducing the code size 20:31 Detail work 23:03 Compression 24:38 Gameplay 25:26 kkrieger final 26:47 TheProdukkt is no more 28:01 Credits
üîóVideo Linksüîó BreakPoint 04 Site: https://breakpoint.untergrund.net/2004/general.php .theprodukkt: https://web.archive.org/web/20040810211758/http://www.theprodukkt.com/theprodukkt.html#tech The Farbrausch way: https://llg.cubic.org/docs/farbrauschDemos/ Research Gate: https://www.researchgate.net/figure/The-game-kkrieger-has-a-file-size-of-96-kb_fig1_320722498 Breakpoint 2004: https://breakpoint.untergrund.net/2004/ Assembly seminars '04: https://web.archive.org/web/20041204090344/http://www.assembly.org/ fiver2's website: http://www.theunitedstatesofamerica.de/ ryg's homepage: http://www.farbrausch.com/~fg/ gizmo's website: http://www.pixelz.de/ "Metaprogramming for madmen": https://fgiesen.wordpress.com/2012/04/08/metaprogramming-for-madmen/ kkrieger interview from 2004: https://www.gamasutra.com/view/feature/130690/interview_frugal_fragging_with_.php Interview from 2005: https://www.gamasutra.com/view/feature/130690/interview_frugal_fragging_with_.php Github code: https://github.com/farbrausch/fr_public/blob/master/werkkzeug3/genmesh.cpp

item.title: Less is safer: how Obsidian reduces the risk of supply chain attacks
item.description: Supply chain attacks are malicious updates that sneak into open source code used by many apps. Here‚Äôs how we design Obsidian to ensure that the app is a secure and private environment for your thoughts.
